div.p: The original transcription is not available.

Yesterday, a decree was issued – a law about taking the Jewish city estates into ownership of the Romanian state. To make the report complete I add that the agricultural estates in the ownership of Jews have been already taken into the ownership of the state in October 1940.

The new decreed law is thus only considering the estates and the ownership rights of these estates which are located in the cities or villages and which are not of an agricultural character and are owned by Jews. These estates or the ownership rights are thus condemned for a use of the state by this decreed law, and it is irrelevant whether the estates belong physically to one Jewish persons or to a community. […] The Jewish companies are considered those public or business companies where there is at least one Jewish associate, even with limited liability, or where 40% of capital belongs to Jews. The law excuses those Jews (people with one Jewish ancestor regardless of their religion or nationality) who were naturalized by the individual law before 15 August 1916 , who were injured or given a medal of valour on the Romanian side during the war. Further on, it excludes the descendants of those Jews who fell for Romania during the war, the Jews who

are baptised for at least 20 years and married to a Romanian person, the baptised Jews who are married to a Romanian person for at least 10 years and have children of Christian religion from this marriage, the Jews who are baptised for at least 30 years and are the descendants of the above mentioned Jews. The Jews, who have proven to be devoted and who themselves or their predecessors had proven extraordinary services to the country may be exempt by a special decree from the law.
Every Jewish owner of such estates is required to announce their estate or the ownership right to a similar estate within the next 30 days to the Romanisation division of the Ministry of Economy.

False data or concealment will result in the loss of a claim for compensation. The Jews will continue to benefit from the land until they are asked to hand over the land, but until then they are also materially and legally responsible for the land. Non-Jewish co-owners have a preferential right to purchase a Jewish work, provided they notify their proposal to the Romanian Department within 3 months. Compensation for the expropriated Jewish land will be calculated on the basis of the gross-income with which the land has been reported to the tax authorities in recent years and then paid in a 3% rent. Even in the future, Jews will not be able to acquire ownership or other legal property on urban lands (urban areas), except that special districts will establish special quarters,
that would serve exclusively the Jewish population.

The explanatory memorandum of the Minister without Portfolio, Professor Michael Antonescu, states that the land ownership had always been a defence power against intruders in Romania. It was like that even during the Turkish domination. In 19th century, the codex Callimach gave the Jews certain rights in Moldova. Ever since then, the Jews slowly acquired too much of the business and industry as well as of the agricultural and residential estates thanks to the international trade and the pressure of the world powers [...]. Nowadays, the old Romanian ideology is valid again. Property and its national and Christian stratification are becoming an essential part of the new Romanian life. This law is not only a negative policy measure, but also a positive social and economic reform. The land that will be expropriated by the Jews will not become the buisness values ​​that the state will give to individuals, but will become instruments for consolidating [...] society by allocating them to the creative and working elements. With this law, a base for new life force and new creation of Romanian people will be build, in the sense of their history and their mental unity with the world of national freedoms that is emerging in the new Europe.
I would like to add to this law that at the first glance it seems as a law very radically anti-Jewish, however, it all depends on how it will be
executed, especially when it comes to the possible exceptions. Nevertheless, it is another important step of the Romanian government in the practical execution of the anti Jewish politics.
Made in 4 copies, 3 of them for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and 1 copy to be stored within the records.
